item.title: Star jockey 'serious but stable' after fall
item.description: Jockey Michelle Payne was set to make her debut at Royal Ascot next month, but the first female winner of the Melbourne Cup is in a "serious but stable condition" after suffering abdomen injuries in a fall.
item.ExtractedText:
Facebook Twitter Instagram
Michelle Payne: 'Serious but stable' after fall By Rob Hodgetts, CNN Updated 1302 GMT (2102 HKT) May 24, 2016 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Michelle Payne rocked the world of racing by becoming the first female jockey to win the Melbourne Cup at Flemington Racecourse. Hide Caption 1 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' The Melbourne Cup is known as the "race that stops a nation" such is the interest in the event. It's not just the cup that stops Australia -- it's high stakes in the fashion world too. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' The Melbourne Cup was given its own entrance parade ahead of the race. Hide Caption 3 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Australian beauty pageant titleholder and television reporter.Rachael Finch poses at the Myer Marquee on Melbourne Cup Day at Flemington Racecourse. Hide Caption 4 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' The celebrities were out in force with Lleyton Hewitt, the Australian tennis player, just one famous face at the racecourse. Hide Caption 5 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Of course, hats aren't just for women. Here designer Phillip Rhodes poses on Melbourne Cup Day at Flemington Racecourse on November 3, 2015 in Melbourne, Australia. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' There were 24 horses competing for a chance at sporting immortality. Hide Caption 7 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Just the fourth woman to compete in the race in its 155-year history, Payne rode New Zealand-bred Prince of Penzance to victory. Hide Caption 8 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Prince of Penzance cost $36,000 but came up trumps to win the $2.6 million top prize. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Payne was mobbed by adoring fans after her surprise triumph. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Payne, one of 10 kids, celebrated the victory with her family. Hide Caption 11 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Payne celebrated her triumph with brother Stevie, who has Down syndrome. Stevie works as her strapper. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' DJ Nussy was on the decks as she entertained the crowds at Flemington. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Singer Craig David was also on hand to entertain the Flemington masses. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Supported by cello and violins, singer Nathaniel also performed at the racecourse. Hide Caption 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' There was a huge crowd at Flemington to witness Payne's landmark win. Hide Caption 16 of 20 20 photos: Michelle Payne: Australia's 'First Lady' Mobiles were very much at the ready to capture events both on and off the track. Hide Caption
